Article.ArticleTitle: Association and interaction of O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> with emergency room visits for respiratory diseases in Beijing, China: a time-series study.

AbstractText: Ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) and nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) are the two main gaseous pollutants in the atmosphere that act as oxidants. Their short-term effects and interaction on emergency room visits (ERVs) for respiratory diseases remain unclear.

We conducted a time-series study based on 144,326 ERVs for respiratory diseases of Peking University Third Hospital from 2014 to 2019 in Beijing, China. Generalized additive models with quasi-Poisson regression were performed to analyze the association of O<sub>3</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub> and their composite indicators (O<sub>x</sub> and O<sub>x</sub><sup>wt</sup>) with ERVs for respiratory diseases. An interaction model was further performed to evaluate the interaction between O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub>.

Exposure to O<sub>3</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, O<sub>x</sub> and O<sub>x</sub><sup>wt</sup> was positively associated with ERVs for total respiratory diseases and acute upper respiratory infection (AURI). For instance, a 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup> increase in O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> were associated with 0.93% (95%CI: 0.05%, 1.81%) and 5.87% (95%CI: 3.92%, 7.85%) increase in AURI at lag0-5 days, respectively. Significant linear exposure-response relationships were observed in O<sub>x</sub> and O<sub>x</sub><sup>wt</sup> over the entire concentration range. In stratification analysis, stronger associations were observed in the group aged < 18 years for both O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub>, in the warm season for O<sub>3</sub>, but in the cold season for NO<sub>2</sub>. In interaction analysis, the effect of O<sub>3</sub> on total respiratory emergency room visits and AURI visits was the strongest at high levels (> 75% quantile) of NO<sub>2</sub> in the < 18 years group.

Short-term exposure to O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> was positively associated with ERVs for respiratory diseases, particularly in younger people (< 18 years). This study for the first time demonstrated the synergistic effect of O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> on respiratory ERVs, and O<sub>x</sub> and O<sub>x</sub><sup>wt</sup> may be potential proxies.
